As the first or corresponding author (including co-authors), he has published more than 110 papers in leading international journals such as Physical Review Letters, National Science Review, Science Advances, Nature Communications, Nature Reviews Materials, Nature Reviews Physics, Reports on Progress in Physics, and Science Bulletin, among which 14 are ESI highly cited papers. His research results have been selected multiple times as Editorsâ€™ Suggestions and have been featured by media outlets such as APS, AIP, Phys.org, Physics Buzz, and Science Daily. His publications have accumulated over 12,700 citations with an H-index of 52. He has been listed several times among the Highly Cited Researchers and the worldâ€™s top 2% scientists (career impact). He received the First Prize of the Ministry of Education Natural Science Award and the â€œWei Moâ€™an Acoustics Awardâ€ from the Shanghai Acoustical Society, and his students won the National Gold Medal of the China International College Students Innovation Competition. Patents related to acoustic metamaterial absorbers have been successfully transferred and applied to national large-scale wind-tunnel compressor noise-reduction systems, achieving low-noise operation of major equipment. ğŸ”Š Major Academic AchievementsTheory of Acoustic Metasurface Manipulation â€” â€œSmall Structures Controlling Large Fieldsâ€: To address the challenge of low-frequency acoustic manipulation, Professor Li extended metasurface concepts into acoustics, realizing the control of low-frequency sound fields with compact structures. By introducing loss degrees of freedom to construct non-Hermitian acoustic metasurfaces, he revealed new physical meanings of loss in acoustic control, providing new approaches for miniaturized acoustic devices. Theory of Broadband Acoustic Absorption â€” â€œFrom Narrow to Broadâ€: To solve the problem of broadband acoustic control, he proposed a new mechanism of resonant coupling among weakly absorbing units, revealing how coupling effects enhance absorption bandwidth. Lightweight and thin broadband acoustic metasurface absorbers were fabricated, achieving efficient control of low-frequency broadband acoustic fields. Theory of Acoustic-Liner Noise Reduction â€” â€œSilence in Motionâ€: To tackle acoustic control under complex flow environments, he uncovered the mechanism of multimodal helical sound waves interacting with metasurfaces under high-speed airflow and developed a new metasurface-based acoustic-liner noise-reduction technology, enabling effective noise control of equipment operating under extreme conditions.â€“> ğŸ§  Research Interests1. Manipulation of Exotic Acoustic Fields in Functional Materials The group focuses on the fundamental study of acoustic field manipulation in engineered and functional materials, exploring the mechanisms of sound propagation, interference, and localization in complex media. Key topics include resonance coupling, wavefront shaping, and nonreciprocal transmission. The research aims to uncover the intrinsic physics of soundâ€“matter interactions and provide theoretical foundations for precise acoustic energy control and novel functional devices. 2. Applications of Acoustic Functional MaterialsThe group conducts systematic studies on functional acoustic materials, focusing on deep-subwavelength metastructures and multifunctional composites for broadband and low-frequency sound absorption. The research aims to optimize absorption performance through the interplay of resonance, coupling, interference, and dissipation. Integrating theoretical modeling with material innovation, we advance the application of acoustic materials in noise mitigation, precision acoustic design, and transportation and aerospace systems. 3. Non-Hermitian and Topological Acoustics Our group conducts systematic research on non-Hermitian physics and topological wave phenomena in acoustics, focusing on the realization and physical mechanisms of gain/loss modulation, exceptional points (EPs), and topological edge states. We aim to uncover new principles governing nonreciprocal sound transport, ultrasensitive modal coupling, and robust energy transfer. By constructing non-Hermitian topological insulators and nonreciprocal topological waveguides, the research provides theoretical and design foundations for next-generation acoustic communication,
